subsections.title: 6.3	FR2 Feasibility Evaluation
subsections.text_content:
RAN4 perform feasibility study on FR2 HST scenario, by at least considering following aspects:
1)	The feasibility of a deployment based the beam dwelling time and measurement period framework:
a)	How many beams/SSBs per RRH can be deployed (given other deployment parameters such as Dmin, Ds, speed etc) while maintain mobility performance with FR2 BM mechanism?; and
b)	How much beam refinement is needed to achieve coverage and mobility?
-	How much beam overlapping area is needed (given other deployment parameters such as Dmin, Ds, speed etc.) to ensure beam refinement procedure can be executed successfully?
2)	Study throughput performance and mobility performance:
a)	More number of analogue beams and sharper beam may provide better link budget performance but more challenging on mobility performance.
3)	Receive timing difference.
4)	Maximum supported Doppler shift for both UL and DL and maximum supported UE speed.
Other feasibility study is not precluded.

For evaluating the maximum supported speed following numerology will be considered:
-	For FR2 HST evaluations and possible performance requirements definition, RAN4 only consider 120kHz SCS as baseline assumption.

subsubsections.title: 6.3.1	Idle/inactive mode
6.3.2	Connected mode
subsubsections.text_content:
RAN4 discussed the Rx beam number for RRM requirements definition and agreed to define two sets of enhanced RRM requirements in terms of the number of Rx beams (i.e., Rx beam sweeping scaling factor) per UE:
-	Set 1: 2 Rx beams
-	Set 2: 6 Rx beams
Set 1 is more relevant to the deployments where the RRHs are located next to the railway track, e.g., like in Scenario-A with Dmin = 10m. Whereases, Set 2 can be used in the scenarios where RRHs are further away from the track, e.g., like Scenario-B with Dmin=150m.
The analysis below is based on the system-level simulations carried out following the assumptions and parameters from Table 6.3.8.1-1.
It was found out that in priority scenarios additional beams oriented upwards (i.e., up from the horizontal plane parallel to the railways track) do not provide meaningful pefromance gains. Therefore, the analysis below is focusing only on the beams with different orientations in the horizontal plane.
Following the antenna panel parameters from the Section 6.1, the half-power width for the RRH boresight beam is around 12.6 degrees (8x8 panel). Whereas the half-power width of the UE boresight beam is around 26 degrees (4x4 panel).
The considered deployment is uni-directional Scenario-A where the train is traveling in the direction opposite to the serving beam as presented in Figure 6.3.2.1.1-1. It is assumed that the RRH panel is oriented towards the projection of the following RRH on the railway track, and only one beam is used per RRH panel. The UE panel boresight is parallel to the railway track.
Figure 6.3.2.1.1-1 illustrates a high-speed train (HST) frequency range 2 (FR2) uni-directional deployment, where the train is moving towards the serving beam. The figure depicts the train's movement along the track, with the serving beam's direction indicated by the arrow. The deployment showcases the alignment of the train with the beam, ensuring optimal signal reception and communication. The illustration highlights the importance of precise beamforming and positioning in providing reliable and high-speed connectivity for mobile communication systems, such as those used in railway networks.
Figure 6.3.2.1.1-1: HST FR2 Uni-directional deployment, the train is moving towards the serving beam.
In Figure 6.3.2.1.1-2, simulation results (cumulative distribution function of SINR) are shown when only one Rx beam with fixed orientation is configured at the UE. It can be seen that the beam co-oriented with the UE panel’s boresight (RxBeams1-90) provides the highest SINR.
Figure 6.3.2.1.1-2 presents a Cumulative Distribution Function (CDF) of Signal-to-Interference plus Noise Ratio (SINR) for various orientations of a single receive beam in a telecommunication system. The CDF curve illustrates the probability of SINR values for different beam directions, providing insights into the system's performance under different antenna configurations. The figure is essential for optimizing the beamforming process and ensuring reliable communication in the presence of interference.
Figure 6.3.2.1.1-2: CDF of SINR for different orientations of a single Rx beam.
Next, a scenario where multiple Rx beams can be used at the UE side is considered. In Figure 6.3.2.1.1-3, it is demonstrated that no gain from using more than one boresight beam (i.e., the beam 90) is observed even if all of the additional beams are oriented towards the RRH.
Figure 6.3.2.1.1-3 presents a Cumulative Distribution Function (CDF) of Signal-to-Interference plus Noise Ratio (SINR) for various numbers of receive beams in a telecommunication system. The CDF curves are plotted for three different scenarios: 1) 1 Rx beam, 2) 2 Rx beams, and 3) 3 Rx beams. The x-axis represents the SINR values, while the y-axis represents the probability of occurrence. The CDF curves show the likelihood of achieving a certain SINR value for each scenario, illustrating the impact of the number of receive beams on the overall system performance. The figure highlights the trade-off between the number of beams and the SINR distribution, providing insights into the optimal configuration for a given telecommunication system.
Figure 6.3.2.1.1-3: CDF of SINR for different number of Rx beams.
A scheme of uni-directional deployments in HST FR2 Scenario-B is shown in Figure 6.3.2.1.2-1. We also indicate the orientation of Tx beams at RRH and Rx beams at CPE used in the simulations.
Figure 6.3.2.1.2-1 illustrates the schemes of uni- and bi-directional deployments in High Speed Train (HST) Frequency Division Duplex (FR2) Scenario-B with the orientation of Tx and Rx beams. The figure showcases the arrangement of transmit and receive antennas, highlighting the directional nature of the communication system. The uni-directional deployment focuses on a single direction of signal transmission, while the bi-directional deployment enables communication in both directions. The figure emphasizes the importance of antenna positioning and orientation in achieving efficient and reliable communication in high-speed environments.
Figure 6.3.2.1.2-1: The schemes of uni- and bi-directional deployments in HST FR2 Scenario-B with the orientation of Tx and Rx beams.
From Figure 6.3.2.1.2-2 it can be noticed that increasing the number of Tx beams on RRH side provides very minor gain in HST FR2 uni-directional Scenario-B if only one Rx beam is used. Indeed, in this case, the CPE stays mostly in the coverage area of the boresight Tx beam, and additional beams are not used much.
Figure 6.3.2.1.2-2 illustrates the Signal-to-Interference-plus-Noise Ratio (SINR) Cumulative Distribution Function (CDF) in a uni-directional scenario for different numbers of transmit beams when only one receive beam parallel to the track is utilized. The figure showcases the impact of beamforming techniques on signal quality, with varying beam numbers (1, 2, 4, 8, 16) and their corresponding CDFs. The CDF curves indicate the probability of achieving a certain SINR level, providing insights into the system's performance under different beam configurations. The figure highlights the trade-off between beam number and signal quality, with more beams potentially leading to better SINR but also increased complexity and potential interference.
Figure 6.3.2.1.2-2: SINR CDF in uni-directional Scenario-B for different number of Tx beams when only one Rx beam parallel to the track is used.
Firstly, the scenario where one boresight Tx beam is used at the RRH and one Rx beam is used at the UE is considered. Different UE Rx beams directions are compared in Figure 6.3.2.1.2-3. The results demonstrate that Rx beam orientation has a significant impact on performance. For example, wrong orientation of Rx beam (e.g., to the other side from the RRH) results in the significant loss of performance. It was also found that Rx beam oriented 10-15 degrees from the UE panel boresight towards the RRH (i.e., RxBeams1-80, RxBeams1-75) provide best performance in Scenario-B.
Figure 6.3.2.1.2-3 illustrates the L1-RSRP traces of serving RRH (top) and SINR CDFs (bottom) in a uni-directional Scenario-B for different orientations of Rx beams. The figure showcases the impact of beam orientation on signal quality and coverage, with measurements taken from various angles. The top graph displays the Received Signal Strength Indicator (RSSI) of the serving RRH, while the bottom graph represents the Cumulative Distribution Function (CDF) of Signal-to-Interference-plus-Noise Ratio (SINR) values. The results reveal how beam orientation affects the received signal strength and the likelihood of achieving a certain SINR threshold, providing valuable insights for optimizing network performance and coverage in real-world scenarios.Figure 6.3.2.1.2-3 presents the L1-RSRP traces of the serving RRH (top) and the SINR CDFs (bottom) in a uni-directional Scenario-B for various orientations of the receiving beams. The figure illustrates the impact of beam orientation on signal quality and coverage, with measurements taken from different angles. The top graph displays the Received Signal Strength Indicator (RSSI) of the serving RRH, while the bottom graph represents the Cumulative Distribution Function (CDF) of Signal-to-Interference-plus-Noise Ratio (SINR) values. The results reveal how beam orientation affects the received signal strength and the likelihood of achieving a certain SINR threshold, providing valuable insights for optimizing network performance and coverage in real-world scenarios.
Figure 6.3.2.1.2-3: L1-RSRP traces of serving RRH (top) and SINR CDFs (bottom) in uni-directional Scenario-B for different orientations of Rx beams.
Next, it is studied how the performance depends on the orientation of one Rx beam when multiple Tx beams are used. These results are shown in Figure 6.3.2.1.2-4. Like in Figure 6.3.2.1.2-2, one can observe that adding more Tx beams when only one Rx beam parallel to the track is used does not provide significant gain. However, if we orient the Rx beam more towards the RRH, then in the areas next to the RRH the received signal power can be significantly increased.

Figure 6.3.2.1.2-4 illustrates the L1-RSRP traces of the serving RRH (top) and the SINR CDFs (bottom) in a uni-directional Scenario-B with multiple Tx beams and different orientations of Rx beams. The figure showcases the performance of a network under various conditions, highlighting the impact of beamforming and antenna orientation on signal quality and coverage. The top graph displays the L1-RSRP values, which represent the signal strength at the receiver, while the bottom graph presents the cumulative distribution function (CDF) of the signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio (SINR), indicating the probability of achieving a certain SINR level. The figure demonstrates the importance of optimizing beamforming and antenna configurations to ensure reliable and high-quality communication in a wireless network.
Figure 6.3.2.1.2-4: L1-RSRP traces of serving RRH (top) and SINR CDFs (bottom) in uni-directional Scenario-B with multiple Tx beams and for different orientations of Rx beam.
Finally, the scenario where multiple (four) Tx and multiple (up to four) Rx beams are configured together is analyzed (Figure 6.3.2.1.2-5). It is shown that the correct choice of Rx beams improves the received signal strength in the areas where the coverage of additional Tx beams is present. The median value of the SINR can be increased for around 4 dB. One can also notice that the use of 2 and 3 Rx beams provide significant gains, whereases the gain from more additional beams (e.g., 4 in total) is not significant.

Figure 6.3.2.1.2-5 illustrates the L1-RSRP traces of the serving RRH (top) and the SINR CDFs (bottom) in a uni-directional Scenario-B with four Tx and multiple Rx beams. The figure showcases the performance of the network under different conditions, providing valuable insights into the signal strength and coverage. The top graph displays the L1-RSRP traces, which measure the signal strength at the receiver, while the bottom graph presents the cumulative distribution function (CDF) of the signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio (SINR), indicating the probability of achieving a certain SINR level. The figure highlights the importance of optimizing beamforming and resource allocation to ensure reliable and efficient communication in a multi-beam environment.
Figure 6.3.2.1.2-5: L1-RSRP traces of serving RRH (top) and SINR CDFs (bottom) in uni-directional Scenario-B with four Tx and multiple Rx beams.

subsubsections.title: 6.3.3	Link Performance and Throughput Performance
subsubsections.text_content:
Based on the evaluation parameters provided in clause 6.1 and channel modeling provided in clause 6.2, companies are provided evaluation results by examining the link performance and throughput performance. In the following sub-section, companies’ evaluation results are provided for information, which are used as the technical basis to derive the conclusion.
For Scenario-A, uni-directional and bi-directional deployment, Samsung provide the evaluation in the contributions R4-2110234 and R4-2113170 respectively.
As provided in clause 6.2 for the detailed simulation assumption and the detailed beam configuration in Table 6.3.3.1.1-1, it has been shown that with 1 beam per RRH panel and 1 beam per UE panel, the link budget performance is satisfactory, in terms of at least ~30dB margin over FR2 PC4 REFSENS requirement and at least ~21dB margin over FR2 PC4 spherical coverage requirement, as illustrated in following figure. Even considering 31dBm for TX power is a bit optimistic assumption for 8x8 panel configuration (e.g., with per element P_out = 12dBm and 3dB polarization gain, 8x8 panel can achieve 12 + 10log(64) + 3 = 34dBm without considering any implementation margin), the cellular coverage should still be satisfactory with implementation margin considered.
Figure 6.3.3.1.1-1 illustrates the received signal power without user equipment (UE) RX beamforming in a uni-directional scenario, showcasing the impact of antenna gain and antenna directivity on signal strength. The figure depicts the transmit power from the base station (BS) and the received power at the UE, emphasizing the importance of beamforming techniques in enhancing signal quality and coverage.
Figure 6.3.3.1.1-1 RX power without UE RX beamforming, Scenario-A, Uni-directional
Next, we take UE RX beamforming gain into account, and assume 1 beam per panel (which is existing agreement in R4-2106100). For simplicity, it is assumed that UE boresight direction is opposite to RRH boresight direction (i.e., the largest UE beamforming gain is achieved when UE is located at the projection point of the neighboring RRH on the railway). It is shown in the following figure, with UE RX beamforming gain into account, the received signal power after RX beamforming is no less than -50dBm even for the nearest coverage point (which is corresponding to least RX beamforming gain around 15dB), which also should be regarded as satisfactory link performance.
Figure 6.3.3.1.1-2 presents a detailed analysis of the received power with user equipment (UE) RX beamforming in a uni-directional scenario. The figure illustrates the impact of various factors on the received power, including the distance between the base station (BS) and the UE, the antenna gain, and the beamforming gain. The graph shows that the received power increases with the distance, but the rate of increase decreases as the distance becomes larger. This is due to the fact that the signal strength decreases with distance, and the beamforming gain helps to compensate for this decrease. The figure also shows that the received power is higher when the UE is closer to the BS, which is expected since the signal has to travel a shorter distance. Overall, the figure provides valuable insights into the factors that affect the received power in a uni-directional communication scenario.
Figure 6.3.3.1.1-2 RX power with UE RX beamforming, Scenario-A, Uni-directional
The evaluation and analysis above is based on the parameters provided in clause 6.1, while some of additional used assumptions are summarized in the below Table:
Table 6.3.3.1.1-1 Additional Assumptions for Uni-directional RRH Deployment Link Performance Evaluation

Two candidate schemes for Bi-directional deployment for Scenario-A are discussed, and the illustration of two scheme are captured in WF R4-2106100 for information, i.e.,
-	Scheme-1: Connecting to 2nd-Nearest RRH;
-	Scheme-2: Connecting to Nearest RRH except Coverage Hole.

The given telecommunication figure illustrates two different scenarios for connecting to a Remote Radio Head (RRH) in a network. In Scheme-1, the connection is established to the 2nd-Nearest RRH, while in Scheme-2, the connection is made to the Nearest RRH, except in cases where there is a coverage hole. This figure is essential for understanding how to optimize network connectivity and ensure efficient data transmission.       The telecommunication figure presents two distinct scenarios for connecting to a Remote Radio Head (RRH) within a network. In Scheme-1, the connection is established to the 2nd-Nearest RRH, while in Scheme-2, the connection is made to the Nearest RRH, with an exception for cases where there is a coverage hole. This figure is crucial for comprehending how to optimize network connectivity and ensure optimal data transmission.
Scheme-1: Connecting to 2nd-Nearest RRH                                         Scheme-2: Connecting to Nearest RRH except Coverage Hole
Figure 6.3.3.1.2-1 Illustration of Scheme-1 and 2 for bi-directional deployment
Accordingly the link performance of scheme-1 and scheme-2 are provided in the following two figures respectively.
Figure 6.3.3.1.2-2 presents a detailed analysis of the received signal power with user equipment (UE) RX beamforming for Scheme-1, Scenario-A, in a bi-directional communication system. The figure illustrates the impact of various factors, such as antenna gain, antenna directivity, and beamforming gain, on the overall received power. The diagram showcases the relationship between the transmit power, antenna directivity, and beamforming gain, providing valuable insights into the system's performance. The figure also highlights the importance of optimizing these parameters to achieve maximum power transfer efficiency and minimize interference, which is crucial for reliable communication in complex environments.
Figure 6.3.3.1.2-2 RX power with UE RX beamforming for Scheme-1, Scenario-A, Bi-directional
Figure 6.3.3.1.2-3 presents a detailed analysis of the received power with user equipment (UE) RX beamforming for Scheme-2, Scenario-A, in a bi-directional communication system. The figure illustrates the impact of various factors, such as the transmit power, antenna gain, and beamforming gain, on the received power. The diagram showcases the relationship between these parameters and their effect on the overall communication performance. The visual representation of the RX power and UE RX beamforming provides valuable insights into optimizing the system for better performance and reliability.
Figure 6.3.3.1.2-3 RX power with UE RX beamforming for Scheme-2, Scenario-A, Bi-directional

The evaluation and analysis above is based on the parameters provided in clause 6.1, while some of additional used assumptions and the detailed beam configuration in Table 6.3.3.1.2-1 are summarized in the below Table:
Table 6.3.3.1.2-1 Additional Assumptions for Bi-directional RRH Deployment Link Performance Evaluation

Editor Notes: TBA.
Editor Notes: TBA.
For Scenario-A, uni-directional and bi-directional deployment, Huawei provide the evaluation in the contributions R4-2119021 based on simulation assumption as shown in clause 6.1 and Table 6.3.3.2.1-1.
Table 6.3.3.2.1-1 Simulation assumption for Scenario-A

There are two schemes for Bi-directional deployment. Considering very small Dmin, the angle between RRH-UE line and the railway can be negligible, so only Scheme-1 is for further analysis.
Figure 6.3.3.2.1.1-1 presents a bi-directional deployment scheme for a telecommunication network, illustrating the arrangement of transmitter-receiver pairs and the associated signal paths. The figure showcases the use of multiple antennas at the base stations to enhance signal reception and transmission, as well as the strategic placement of relay nodes to improve coverage and reduce latency. The layout emphasizes the importance of efficient resource allocation and optimal network design in achieving high-speed, low-latency communication across the network.
Figure 6.3.3.2.1.1-1 Scheme-1 for Bi-directional deployment
For Scheme-1, 1 beam per RRH panel and 6 beam per UE panel is selected. Note that a single RRH panel or UE panel refers to the antenna configuration in Table 6.3.3.2.1-1. The RRH panel boresight is pointed to the railway at the distance of Ds, the beam is pointed to the railway at the distance of Ds. When the UE is at the distance of Ds, the UE panel boresight is point to RRH panel boresight rightly. The link budget analysis is shown as Figure 6.3.3.2.1.1-2 below.
Figure 6.3.3.2.1.1-2 presents a detailed link budget analysis for Scheme-1, illustrating the various components and their respective efficiencies in terms of signal transmission. The figure showcases the signal power, loss, and noise, providing a comprehensive understanding of the link budget's impact on communication quality. Key elements include the transmitter, receiver, and intermediate nodes, each contributing to the overall signal strength. The figure emphasizes the importance of optimizing these components for maximum communication efficiency.
Figure 6.3.3.2.1.1-2 Link budget for Scheme-1
For Scheme-1, the power of side-lobes for different beams change rapidly when UE is near to the RRH and the minimum time duration for the best beam with same beam index can be far less than 160 ms that is the L1-RSRP measurement period for HST FR2 scenario. It is a great challenge for the UE to ensure the performance not to degrade in such location. UE can use different strategy by implementation, such as select the best beam as per RSRP measurement result or directly switch the UE beam point to the main-lobe beam transmission from the next RRH. For the former one, the best beam may be unavailable with high probability once UE beam switching has been performed.
For Uni-directional deployment, 1 beam per RRH panel and 2 beam per UE panel is selected. Note that a single RRH panel or UE panel refers to the antenna configuration in Table 6.3.3.2.1-1. The RRH panel boresight is pointed to the railway at the distance of Ds, the beam is pointed to 0 degrees. When the UE is at the distance of Ds, the UE panel boresight is point to RRH panel boresight rightly. The link budget analysis is shown as Figure 6.3.3.2.1.2-1 below.
Figure 6.3.3.2.1.2-1 presents a detailed link budget analysis for a uni-directional telecommunication deployment. The figure illustrates the various components involved in the link budget calculation, including the transmitter, receiver, antenna gain, and atmospheric loss. The diagram also accounts for the impact of shadowing, which affects signal strength due to obstacles between the transmitter and receiver. The overall goal is to optimize the link budget to ensure reliable communication under varying environmental conditions.
Figure 6.3.3.2.1.2-1 Link budget for Uni-directional deployment
The link budget remaining and the minimum beam dwelling time for Uni-directional deployment is shown as Table 6.3.3.2.1.2-1 below.
Table 6.3.3.2.1.2-1 Link budget remaining and minimum beam dwelling time

For Scenario-B, uni-directional and bi-directional deployment, Huawei provide the evaluation in the contributions R4-2119022 based on simulation assumption as shown in clause 6.1 and Table 6.3.3.2.2-1.
Table 6.3.3.2.2-1 Simulation assumption for Scenario-B

There are four schemes for Bi-directional deployment are for further analysis.

a) Scheme-1								b) Scheme-2
"Figure 3c illustrates the network architecture of a telecommunication system, showcasing the interconnected nodes and their roles in data transmission. The figure depicts a hub-and-spoke model, with the central hub serving as the primary node for data aggregation and distribution. The spokes represent the various access points, or edge nodes, that connect to the core network. This design allows for efficient data routing and ensures high-speed connectivity for end-users. The figure also highlights the use of multiple paths for redundancy and reliability, as well as the potential for future expansion and integration with other networks."
c) Scheme-3
Figure 6.3.3.2.2.1-1 Candidate schemes for Bi-directional deployment
For Scheme-1, 1 beam per RRH panel and 6 beam per UE panel is selected. Note that a single RRH panel or UE panel refers to the antenna configuration in Table 6.3.3.2.2-1. The RRH panel boresight is pointed to the railway at the distance of Ds, the beam is pointed to the railway at the distance of Ds. When the UE is at the distance of Ds, the UE panel boresight is point to RRH panel boresight rightly. The link budget analysis is shown as Figure 6.3.3.2.2.1-2 below.
Figure 6.3.3.2.2.1-2 presents a detailed link budget analysis for Scheme-1, illustrating the various components and their respective efficiencies in terms of signal power, noise power, and loss. The figure showcases the relationship between the transmitter, the optical fiber, and the receiver, emphasizing the importance of each element in maintaining a strong and reliable connection. The visual representation of the link budget provides a comprehensive understanding of the system's performance, allowing for the identification of potential areas for improvement and optimization.
Figure 6.3.3.2.2.1-2 Link budget for Scheme-1
For Scheme-2, 1 beam for one RRH panel and 2 beams for another RRH panel and 6 beam per UE panel is selected. Note that a single RRH panel or UE panel refers to the antenna configuration in Table 6.3.3.2.2-1. The RRH panel boresight is pointed to the railway at the distance of Ds, the beam is pointed to 0 and 10 degrees. When the UE is at the distance of Ds, the UE panel boresight is point to RRH panel boresight rightly. The link budget analysis is shown as Figure 6.3.3.2.2.1-3 below.
Figure 6.3.3.2.2.1-3 presents a detailed link budget analysis for Scheme-2, illustrating the various components and their respective contributions to the overall signal strength. The figure showcases the transmitter (TX) and receiver (RX) equipment, as well as the signal's path through the air and potential losses due to atmospheric conditions, such as rain attenuation and shadowing. The inclusion of the noise figure (NF) and the noise power spectral density (N0) emphasizes the importance of signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) in communication systems. The figure also highlights the impact of different antenna gains and the role of the cable loss (CL) in the overall link budget. This analysis is crucial for optimizing the performance of wireless communication systems, ensuring reliable and efficient data transmission.
Figure 6.3.3.2.2.1-3 Link budget for Scheme-2
For Scheme-3, 2 beam per RRH panel and 6 beam per UE panel is selected. The RRH panel boresight is pointed to the railway at the distance of Ds, the beam is pointed to 0 and 10 degrees. When the UE is at the distance of Ds, the UE panel boresight is point to RRH panel boresight rightly. The link budget analysis is shown as Figure 6.3.3.2.2.1-4 below.
Figure 6.3.3.2.2.1-4 presents a detailed link budget analysis for Scheme-3, illustrating the various components and their respective efficiencies in terms of signal power, noise power, and loss. The figure showcases the link budget formula, which is a crucial aspect of telecommunication systems, as it quantifies the amount of power that can be received at the receiver's end. The visual representation of the link budget components, such as the transmitter, optical fiber, and receiver, provides a comprehensive understanding of the factors affecting signal strength and reliability. The figure emphasizes the importance of optimizing each component to maximize the overall link budget and ensure effective communication.
Figure 6.3.3.2.2.1-4 Link budget for Scheme-3
The link budget remaining and the minimum beam dwelling time for three schemes are shown as Table 6.3.3.2.2.1-1 below.
Table 6.3.3.2.2.1-1 Link budget remaining and minimum beam dwelling time

For Uni-directional deployment, 2 beams per RRH panel and 6 beam per UE panel is selected. The RRH panel boresight is pointed to the railway at the distance of Ds, the beam is pointed to 0 and 10 degrees. When the UE is at the distance of Ds, the UE panel boresight is point to RRH panel boresight rightly. The link budget analysis is shown as Figure 6.3.3.2.2.2-1 below.
Figure 6.3.3.2.2.2-1 presents a detailed link budget analysis for a uni-directional telecommunication deployment. The figure illustrates the various components involved in the link budget calculation, including the transmitter, receiver, antenna gain, and atmospheric loss. The diagram also highlights the importance of signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) and bit error rate (BER) in determining the overall performance of the communication link. The visual representation provides a comprehensive understanding of the factors that influence the link budget in a uni-directional telecommunication system.
Figure 6.3.3.2.2.2-1 Link budget for Uni-directional deployment
The link budget remaining and the minimum beam dwelling time for Uni-directional deployment is shown as Table 6.3.3.2.2.2-1 below.
Table 6.3.3.2.2.2-1 Link budget remaining and minimum beam dwelling time

For scenario A and B, uni- and bi-directional scenarios, Ericsson provided evaluation in contributions R4-2104679 and R4-2104680. The analysis has been performed using the antenna array configurations in sections 6.1.1 and 6.1.3.

For this scenario, it was assumed that the RRHis positioned such that the antenna(s) face directly along the track; i.e. a zero degree steered beam is parallel to the track (in both azimuth and elevation). The UE on the train is positioned such that it’s antenna(s) point directly along the track.
Zero beam steering was assumed, and so the RRHbeam points along the track (but is 10m away from the track) and the UE beam points along the track.
These assumptions are not fully optimal, but they are sufficient to demonstrate that a single TX and a single RX beam is sufficient.
The antenna radiation patterns in azimuth for the UE and RRHare depicted in figure 6.3.3.3.1-1. The array is symmetrical in both axes, so the elevation patterns are the same as the azimuth patterns.



Figure 6.3.3.3.1-1: RRH and UE antenna radiation patterns in azimuth (Elevation patterns are the same)
The most critical link for coverage is the uplink. Thus, the uplink was modelled considering 23dBm transmitter power for the UE. For a train mounted UE, this may be an underestimate for the power.
The coverage pattern for the single TX / RX beam is depicted in figure 6.3.3.3.1-3. A uni-directional deployment is considered in which the RRHantenna is pointing in the direction of movement of the train and the UE antenna away from the direction of movement of the train. The x axis represents the distance along the track from the point on the track that is closest to the RRH. (That implies, at zero on the x axis the UE on the side is parallel to the RRH which is 10m away from the side of the track). The y axis represents UL SNR assuming 10dB noise figure at the RRH

Figure 6.3.3.3.1-2 illustrates a telecommunication network's unidirectional deployment scenario, focusing on the signal flow from the transmitter to the receiver. The figure showcases the various components involved, including the transmitter, multiple relay nodes, and the receiver. The signal's path is depicted through the network, highlighting the role of each node in amplifying and directing the signal. The figure emphasizes the importance of efficient signal routing and the potential for signal loss or interference at certain points in the network.
Figure 6.3.3.3.1-2: Unidirectional deployment scenario

As can be seen in the figure, good coverage is obtained when the train is further than 60-70m along the track from the RRH. Furthermore, the SNR remains good from 700-800m; i.e. the SNR from the RRHat position zero on the track is still good as the UE passes the next RRH (located at 700m along the track)

Figure 6.3.3.3.1-3 illustrates the uplink signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) for a single transmitter (TX) and single receiver (RX) beam in a telecommunication system. The figure shows the relationship between the transmit power (PTX) and the received power (PRX) at the receiver, with the SNR calculated as the ratio of the received power to the noise power. The figure highlights the importance of optimizing beamforming and power allocation for improving the communication quality and reliability in wireless networks. The depicted scenario demonstrates the impact of various factors, such as channel conditions and interference, on the performance of the communication system.
Figure 6.3.3.3.1-3: UL SNR for single TX and single RX beam

Using DPS, the UE can switch RRH after travelling around 60-70m along the track from RRH2 in the figure. Assuming that this is the case, then the SNR observed when travelling along the track is as depicted in figure 4. For downlink, the SNR will be greater.

Figure 6.3.3.3.1-4 illustrates the uplink signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) in a cellular network, assuming a single transmitter/receiver beam and dynamic power control (DPS) switching between remote radio heads (RRHs). The figure depicts the base station (BS), user equipment (UE), and multiple RRHs, with the DPS mechanism enabling efficient power allocation and interference mitigation. The SNR values are crucial for determining the quality of communication and coverage in the network.
Figure 6.3.3.3.1-4: UL SNR assuming single TX/RX beam and DPS switching between RRH

Based on this analysis, we observe that in scenario 1, in a uni-directional deployment it is sufficient to operate with a single TX beam and a single RX beam.

Uni-directional deployment in Scenario A provides very good coverage. Bi-directional deployment would require connection to the second nearest basestation when the UE would be within around 50m from a basestation due to the large azimuth angle to the nearest RRH at that point. Thus, bi-directional deployment would require double the antenna infrastructure at basestations with no coverage or capacity gain.
If RRH are equipped with two antenna, improved throughput can be obtained by operating each direction as an independent uni-directional UE. In a future release, multi-antenna single UE operation may also be introduced.

To consider the number of beams and coverage, a deployment has been analyzed considering scenario B. The RRH antennas are rotated by 13 degrees towards the track, whilst the UE antenna points parallel to the track. Up to 3 RRH beams and up to 2 UE beams are considered. Uplink SNR is considered for depicting the coverage of the beams, since UL SNR is the most critical scenario. DL SNR will be larger than UL SNR.
The x axis represents the distance along the track from the point on the track that is closest to the RRH. (That implies, at zero on the x axis the UE on the side is parallel to the RRH, which is 150m away from the side of the track). The y axis represents UL SNR assuming 10dB noise figure at the RRH and 23dBm UE TRP.

Figure 6.3.3.3.3-1 illustrates the coverage of RRH beam 1 and UE beam 1, showcasing the signal strength distribution across different areas. The figure displays a 3D representation of the radio access network, with the RRH (Remote Radio Head) and UE (User Equipment) locations marked. The color gradient represents the signal strength, with darker shades indicating weaker signals and lighter shades indicating stronger signals. The figure highlights the importance of optimizing RRH and UE beamforming to ensure optimal coverage and minimize interference, which is crucial for providing reliable connectivity to mobile devices in various locations.
Figure 6.3.3.3.3-1: Coverage of RRH beam 1 + UE beam 1

Figure 6.3.3.3.3-2 illustrates the coverage of RRH beam 2 and UE beam 1, showcasing the effective range and signal strength at different locations within a cellular network. The figure demonstrates how the radio resource control (RRC) protocol manages radio frequency (RF) chains and radio bearer setup, ensuring optimal resource allocation. The coverage map highlights the importance of beamforming and power control in enhancing signal quality and reducing interference. The figure also emphasizes the role of base station (BS) and user equipment (UE) in coordinating network operations and maintaining seamless connectivity.
Figure 6.3.3.3.3-2: Coverage of RRH beam 2 + UE beam 1

Figure 6.3.3.3.3-3 illustrates the coverage of RRH beam 3 and UE beam 2, showcasing the overlapping areas where the radio resource (RRH) and user equipment (UE) beams intersect. This overlapping region is crucial for efficient communication between the base station (BS) and the user equipment (UE), as it allows for the transmission of signals without interference. The figure highlights the importance of precise beamforming and alignment in 5G networks to maximize coverage and ensure seamless connectivity.
Figure 6.3.3.3.3-3: Coverage of RRH beam 3 + UE beam 2

Figure 6.3.3.3.3-1 indicates that the first RRH beam can provide coverage from around 300-400m along the track to around 1km along the track. This means that the RRH can provide coverage to a point well beyond the following RRH. Figures 6.3.3.3.3-2 and 6.3.3.3.3-3 indicate that the remaining beams can provide coverage closer to the RRH.
There is little point in providing more beams. Beam 3 provides coverage from around 100-150m from the RRH. Closer to the RRH, beam 1 from the previous RRH is able to provide coverage. Further beams closer to the RRH would be narrow in coverage and do not improve SNR.
Figure 6.3.3.3.3-4 indicates the SNR if a single TX/RX beam (beam 1) is used and coverage close to the RRH is provided from the previous/next RRH. The figure indicates that good UL SNR of above 15dB (DL SNR will be larger than this) can be provided along the length of the track with one TX and one RX beam.

Figure 6.3.3.3.3-4 illustrates the coverage provided by a network of radio access nodes (RRHs) and user equipment (UEs) with 1 beam per RRH and UE antenna. The figure shows the signal propagation from the next and previous RRH, demonstrating how the network efficiently utilizes multiple beams to enhance coverage and reduce interference. The figure highlights the importance of precise beamforming and antenna placement in modern wireless networks.
Figure 6.3.3.3.3-4: Coverage provided from next and previous RRH with 1 beam per RRH and UE antenna.

Figure 6.3.3.3.3-5 depicts the coverage obtained with 3 beams per RRH antenna and 2 beams per UE antenna, considering both the current and previous RRH. The figure shows that the lowest SNR level can be improved a few dB compared to the single beam case.

Figure 6.3.3.3.3-5 illustrates the coverage provided by a radio access network (RAN) consisting of two radio resource control (RRH) units, each equipped with multiple antennas. The figure depicts three beams per RRH antenna and two beams per user equipment (UE) antenna, indicating the network's ability to simultaneously serve multiple users in the same geographical area. The coverage area is visually represented, showcasing the network's reach and capacity to support a large number of connected devices. The figure highlights the importance of efficient antenna configurations in enhancing network performance and capacity.
Figure 6.3.3.3.3-5: Coverage provided from next and previous RRH with 3 beams per RRH antenna and 2 beams per UE antenna.

Thus, we observe that it is perfectly feasible to assume just on beam per antenna also for scenario B as long as the RRH antenna is oriented slightly towards the track. There is some scope for further optimization if 3 RRH / 2 UE beams are considered. Also, allowing for more beams offers more robustness for covering track curves.

For bi-directional deployment, half of the distance along the track would be covered by one RRH and the other half by the following RRH

Figure 6.3.3.3.4-1 illustrates a bi-directional deployment scenario in a telecommunication network, showcasing the interaction between the core network, access network, and transport network. The core network, represented by the central hub, handles high-capacity traffic and is connected to the access network through the transport network. The figure highlights the use of multiple access technologies, such as Ethernet and Wi-Fi, to provide seamless connectivity for both upstream and downstream data flows. The deployment scenario emphasizes the importance of efficient network design and management to ensure optimal performance and reliability in today's interconnected world.
Figure 6.3.3.3.4-1: Bi-directional deployment scenario

The figure below depicts the achievable coverage using 3 beams at the RRH and 3 beams at the UE, with the RRH and UE antennas pointed parallel to the track. After 350m along the track, coverage would be provided by the next RRH. To avoid a break in coverage close to the RRH, the next nearest RRH should be used to serve the UE when it is close in to a RRH.

Figure 6.3.3.3.4-2 illustrates the uplink signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) in a cellular network with three beams per user equipment (UE) and two radio access network (RAN) hub (RRH) units in each direction. The figure showcases dynamic power control (DPS) switching between beams, which optimizes the transmission efficiency. The presence of multiple beams and RRH units highlights the network's capacity to handle high traffic and improve coverage.
Figure 6.3.3.3.4-2: UL SNR with 3 beams per UE and RRH in each direction with DPS switching between beams and RRH

The throughput CDFs are obtained from fully dynamic system-level simulations, which were carried out to evaluate RRM requirements and mobility performance under high-speed train scenarios in FR2. Simulations were performed with train speed 350 km/h in both uni-directional Scenario-A and -B. In bi-directional case only throughput results for Scenario-B are covered. 50MHz channel bandwidth is assumed.
The results include “non-SFN and non-DPS” (i.e., without DPS) transmission scheme analysis corresponding to L3-mobility based on the traditional HO procedure. In these simulations, it is assumed that each BBU has only one RRH corresponding to a more challenging mobility scenario due to longer delays. Alternatively, simulation results for Dynamic Point Selection (DPS) deployments assume that all RRHs are connected to the same BBU, i.e., the mobility is based on L1 measurements and is provided by beam management procedures instead of HO.
On the RRH side, the number of Tx beams is chosen according to the deployment, i.e., only 1 Tx beam in Scenario-A, and 1 or 2 Tx beams in Scenario-B.
The simulation assumptions and parameters for the evaluation of mobility performance are shown in Table 6.3.8.1-1 6.3.4.1.1-1 and 6.3.4.1.2-1 without DRX.
Throughput statistics are shown in figures 6.3.3.4-1, 6.3.3.4-2, 6.3.3.4-3, 6.3.3.4-4, 6.3.3.4-5, 6.3.3.4-6, 6.3.3.4-7 and 6.3.3.4-8. The used metric is windowed user (CPE) throughput where each sample represents average throughput over 100 ms window of the CPE. The maximum achievable CPE throughput in this scenario setting with 50 MHz and maximum modulation 64QAM is about 300 Mbps when there is only one CPE served by a cell at a time. Both the performance with enhanced RRM requirements (Req: Enhanced) and legacy RRM requirements (Req: Legacy) are shown in the figures.
The results demostrate that in the investigated uni-directional scenarios maximum throughput is achieved over 90% of the time. The reason for such a high performance is that there is only one CPE in the simulated area at a time creating very favorable interference conditions. Propagation condition is fully LOS, which causes the coverage area of a RRH to be long along the track. Also, mobility performance (see 6.3.4.1) in non-DRX case is sufficient to keep CPE most of the time in the cell and beam with good signal conditions. In the uni-directional scenario where train is traveling to opposite direction than RRH beams are pointing to the throughput performance tends to be lower than in the cases where train is traveling to the same direction as RRH beams are pointing to. The reason for this is in the mobility performance that is clearly better in the same direction case. However, enhanced requirements clearly also improve the throughput performance of the opposite direction case. The throughputs in DPS deployment are higher than without DPS in all uni-directional cases.
In the bi-directional scenarios maximum throughputs are achieved more seldom i.e., 40-60% of the window samples. One reason, why throughput in bi-directional Scenario-B is not optimal might be because UE is not connected to the closest RRH but to the next closest one, e.g., like it is shown in Figure 5.2.2-3. Bi-directional scenarios are also affected by more frequent handovers and beam switches compared to uni-directional scenarios, which can cause small breaks in data transmission affecting throughput for some of the sampled windows. However, also bi-directional scenario throughput performance gets better when enhanced RRM requirements are applied, despite the lower number of Rx beam options in use compared to legacy RRM requirements. The delay in switching to a better cell or beam gets lower with enhanced requirements. The throughputs in DPS deployment are higher than without DPS in all bi-directional cases.
Figure 6.3.3.4-1 illustrates the windowed user throughput in a uni-directional scenario without dynamic power control (DPS) in a telecommunication network. The graph depicts the relationship between the window size and the average user throughput, showing how varying the window size affects the overall network performance. The x-axis represents the window size, while the y-axis represents the average user throughput in bits per second. The curve illustrates that as the window size increases, the average user throughput also increases, reaching a point of diminishing returns. This indicates that there is an optimal window size that maximizes network efficiency while minimizing latency. The figure highlights the importance of selecting an appropriate window size for effective communication in telecommunication networks.
Figure 6.3.3.4-1: Windowed user throughput in uni-directional Scenario-A without DPS

Figure 6.3.3.4-2 illustrates the windowed user throughput in a uni-directional scenario with dynamic power control (DPS) in a wireless network. The graph shows the relationship between the window size and the average user throughput, demonstrating how varying the window size can impact network performance. The figure highlights the impact of DPS on improving throughput efficiency and managing resource allocation in a multi-user environment.
Figure 6.3.3.4-2: Windowed user throughput in uni-directional Scenario-A with DPS

Figure 6.3.3.4-3 illustrates the windowed user throughput in a uni-directional Scenario-B without dynamic power control (DPS) for a radio access network (RRH) with one beam. The figure depicts the performance of the network under various conditions, showcasing the impact of different parameters on the overall throughput. The graph shows that as the number of users increases, the throughput also increases, indicating that the network can handle a higher load without compromising performance. Additionally, the figure highlights the importance of beamforming techniques in improving the signal-to-noise ratio and enhancing the overall throughput. The results presented in the figure demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed system in providing high-quality communication services to users in a dynamic and challenging environment.
Figure 6.3.3.4-3: Windowed user throughput in uni-directional Scenario-B without DPS (RRHBeams:1)

Figure 6.3.3.4-4 illustrates the windowed user throughput in a uni-directional Scenario-B with Dynamic Power Control (DPS) in a multi-antenna Radio Access Network (RAN) using Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiple Access (OFDMA). The figure depicts the performance of the system under varying conditions, showcasing the impact of different parameters on the overall throughput. The graph displays the relationship between the number of users and the throughput, highlighting the trade-offs between user fairness and overall system efficiency. The figure also includes a legend to explain the different symbols and colors used to represent various system components and parameters.
Figure 6.3.3.4-4: Windowed user throughput in uni-directional Scenario-B with DPS (RRHBeams:1)

Figure 6.3.3.4-5 illustrates the windowed user throughput in a uni-directional Scenario-B without dynamic power control (DPS) for a radio resource block (RRH) with two beams. The graph shows the relationship between the number of users (U) and the total throughput (T) in kbps, with the x-axis representing the number of users and the y-axis representing the total throughput. The curve demonstrates that as the number of users increases, the total throughput also increases, but at a decreasing rate, indicating a limit to the number of users that can be accommodated without sacrificing throughput. The figure highlights the importance of dynamic power control in optimizing the performance of a wireless network.
Figure 6.3.3.4-5: Windowed user throughput in uni-directional Scenario-B without DPS (RRHBeams:2)

Figure 6.3.3.4-6 illustrates the windowed user throughput in a uni-directional Scenario-B with Dynamic Power Control (DPS) in a multi-antenna Radio Access Network (RAN) using Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiple Access (OFDMA). The figure depicts the performance of the system under varying conditions, showcasing the impact of different parameters on the overall throughput. The graph displays the relationship between the number of users and the throughput, highlighting the trade-offs between user fairness and overall system efficiency. The figure also includes a legend to explain the different symbols and colors used to represent various system components and parameters.
Figure 6.3.3.4-6: Windowed user throughput in uni-directional Scenario-B with DPS (RRHBeams:2)

Figure 6.3.3.4-7 illustrates the windowed user throughput in a bi-directional scenario without dynamic power control (DPS) in Scenario-B. The graph shows the relationship between the number of users and the total throughput, with different window sizes and user distributions. The x-axis represents the number of users, ranging from 1 to 10, while the y-axis represents the total throughput in bits per second. The graph demonstrates that as the number of users increases, the total throughput also increases, but at a decreasing rate. This indicates that there is a limit to the number of users that can be supported without sacrificing throughput. The different lines on the graph correspond to different window sizes, with larger windows generally resulting in higher throughput. The shaded area around each line represents the variability in throughput due to the random distribution of users. Overall, this figure provides valuable insights into the performance of a bi-directional communication system without DPS under varying user conditions.
Figure 6.3.3.4-7: Windowed user throughput in bi-directional Scenario-B without DPS

Figure 6.3.3.4-8 illustrates the windowed user throughput in a bi-directional Scenario-B with Dynamic Power Control (DPS) in a telecommunication network. The figure depicts the network's capacity to handle simultaneous data transmissions in both directions, showcasing the impact of DPS on overall throughput. Key visual elements include the sender and receiver nodes, signal strength indicators, and the DPS control mechanisms. The figure highlights the efficiency gains achieved through optimized power allocation and efficient resource management in high-density communication scenarios.
Figure 6.3.3.4-8: Windowed user throughput in bi-directional Scenario-B with DPS

subsubsections.title: 6.3.4	Mobility Performance
subsubsections.text_content:
RAN4 discussed the RX beam number for RRM requirements definition and agreed to define two set of requirements for Scenario A and Scenario B in terms of number of RX beams per UE:
-	Scenario A: [2] RX beams for all scenarios.
-	Scenario B: [6] RX beams for all scenarios.
NOTE: 	if there is insignificant difference between Scenario A and B requirements, then further discussion on unified requirements can take place
For RRC CONNECTED mode requirements for DRX (based on GtW):
-	Define requirements for the short DRX configurations (≤ [80] ms).
Handover:
-	Existing FR2 requirement should be applicable to the HST FR2 deployments when the target cell is known.
Requirements on inter-frequency measurements:
-	Do not define inter-frequency measurements requirements for FR2 HST.
Requirements on inter-RAT measurements:
-	Do not define inter-RAT measurements requirements for FR2 HST.
Measurement procedures:
1)	Cell identification - PSS/SSS detection:
-	Option1: The Cell identification - PSS/SSS detection requirements shall be enhanced.
2)	Cell identification - Intra-frequency measurements:
-	Option 1: The intra-frequency measurement requirement shall be enhanced.
3)	Restriction on SMTC periodicity:
-	Restriction on SMTC periodicity configuration are preferred in FR2 HST.
4)	CSI-RS based L3 measurements:
-	The analysis of the requirements to be de-prioritized.
L1 measurements:
-	The L1 measurements shall be enhanced.
The simulation results are obtained from fully dynamic system-level simulations, which were carried out to evaluate RRM requirements and mobility performance under high-speed train scenarios in FR2. Simulations were performed with train speed 350 km/h in both uni- and bi-directional Scenario-A and -B.
The results include “non-SFN and non-DPS” (i.e., without DPS) transmission scheme analysis corresponding to L3-mobility based on the traditional HO procedure. In these simulations, it is assumed that each BBU has only one RRH creating a more challenging mobility scenario due to longer delays. Alternatively, simulation results for Dynamic Point Selection (DPS) deployments assume that all RRHs are connected to the same BBU, i.e., the mobility is based on L1 measurements and is provided by beam management procedures instead of HO.
Additionally, different settings are considered for DRX configurations in CONNECTED mode, including DRX disabled and DRX cycles of 40, 80, and 160 ms.
On the RRH side, the number of Tx beams is chosen according to the deployment, i.e., only 1 Tx beam in Scenario-A, and 1 or 2 Tx beams in Scenario-B.
Non-ideal PDCCH model is used with Aggregation Level (AL) 16.
The simulation assumptions and parameters for the evaluation of mobility performance are shown in Table 6.3.8.1-1. The differences from these parameters are explicitly described in the sections below.
In the sub-sections below the mobility performance results in HST FR2 deployments based on legacy, i.e., not enhanced, FR2 requirements are presented.
In Table 6.3.4.1.1-1, we show parameters that are different from the ones presented in Table 6.3.8.1-1.
Table 6.3.4.1.1-1: Legacy simulation assumptions for mobility performance evaluation.

Figure 6.3.4.1.1.1-1 shows successful handover rate per CPE per second and ping-pong rate as percentage of ping-pong handovers per all handovers. Ping-pong handover is observed when two handovers happen back and forth between two same cells in one second. It is observed that handover and ping-pong rates are the highest without DRX and gradually decrease when DRX cycle is increased. Significant drop in successful handovers is observed when train travels to opposite direction than RRH beams are pointed to and DRX is used. Ping-pongs are not observed in the cases with DRX configured.

The coverage of the open-space RRHs at the tunnel entrance/exit is likely limited since the RRH beams can be blocked by the tunnel’s outer wall. This is expected to have impacts to mobility performance in uni-directional deployment when the train is approaching/leaving the tunnel from/to the open space. This section demonstrates mobility performance such transition scenario. The aim is to provides insights on the impact of potential coverage issue at the tunnel entrance/exit to the mobility performance.

Figure 6.3.4.1.2 - Coverage issue at the tunnel entrance in uni-directional deployment - illustrates a coverage issue at the tunnel entrance in a uni-directional deployment. The figure shows a telecommunication network with a tunnel entrance, where the signal strength drops significantly, resulting in poor coverage. This issue is particularly pronounced in uni-directional deployments, where the signal only travels in one direction. The figure highlights the importance of proper planning and infrastructure design to ensure adequate coverage in such scenarios. Key components include the base station, user equipment, and the tunnel entrance, with the coverage issue being the focal point of the analysis.
Figure 6.3.4.1.2.11-1 Coverage issue at the tunnel entrance in uni-directional deployment

The assumptions and setting for the simulation are as follows. Uni-directional deployment is considered for the RRH deployed outside the tunnel (RRH1 in Figure 6.3.4.1.2.11-2). Assume that the beam’s main lobe from RRH1 is pointing to the entrance/exit of the tunnel. Depending on the tunnel’s dimension, the LoS paths can be seen up to d [m] inside the tunnel, meaning that NLoS-only condition will exist after distance d. To enable the NLoS condition, the probability of LoS [TR38.901] in the channel model is set as

Distance d is given as d=300m for Scenario A and d=22.6m for Scenario B following the below assumption and estimation. Assume that a tunnel with dimensions:
-	width (w) = 6m, and height (DTunnel,height ) = 5.5m
-	Open space RRH:  DRRH,height = 15m; CPE : DUE,height = 5m
It can be estimated that the coverage of RRH1’s beam behind the tunnel entrance/exit in vertical and horizonal direction are 300 m and 22.1 m for Scenario A, and 14.3m and 22.6m for Scenario B, respectively (Figure 6.3.4.1.2.11-1 for the calculation).

Figure 6.3.4.1.2.11-2 illustrates the calculation of Line-of-Sight (LoS) coverage of a Radio Remote Head (RRH) within a tunnel. The figure depicts the tunnel's interior, with the RRH's beam pattern represented by concentric circles emanating from the RRH's location. The coverage area is calculated based on the beam's width and the distance between the RRH and the points within the tunnel. The figure highlights the importance of accurate beamwidth and positioning for optimal signal coverage in such confined spaces.
Figure 6.3.4.1.2.11-2 Calculation of LoS coverage of RRH1’s beam inside the tunnel.
Then, d=300m for Scenario A and d=22.6m for Scenario B which are probably the best possible case for the LoS channel condition at the tunnel entrance/exit.
Only non-DPS scheme (HO-based) is considered as the assumption is that open-space RRHs belong to different cell than those in the tunnel. However, the results for DPS scheme are expected similar. Other RRM parameters for the simulation follow the enhanced settings in Table 6.3.4.1.2-1.
The mobility robustness performances, which are measured by the time-of-outage and mobility failure rate, are presented.

This section shows the mobility performance when the train is moving into the tunnel from Scenario A (i.e., corresponding to when the train is traveling to the same direction as RRH beam is pointing to, see Figure 6.3.4.1.2.11-1-(a)), and leaving the tunnel to the open space (i.e., corresponding to when the train is traveling to the opposite direction than RRH beams are pointing to, see Figure 6.3.4.1.2.11-1(b)).

Mobility performance in open-space scenarios:
In the previous sections (6.3.4.1.1.1, 6.3.4.1.1.2, 6.3.4.1.2.1, 6.3.4.1.2.2), it was demonstrated that HST FR2 Scenario-A deployment (Figure 6.3.4.1.3-1) where the train is travelling in the direction opposite to serving beam orientation may experience mobility challenges when DRX cycle of 40 ms is used with legacy requirements. This happens due to the very fast degradation of serving RRH signal (Figure 6.3.4.1.3-2). However, there is a significant improvement in Scenario-A from enhanced requirements compared to legacy requirements. With enhanced requirements, mobility robustness is sufficient when DRX cycle of 40 ms is used, but problems can be observed when DRX cycle is increased to 80 ms when the train is travelling in the direction opposite to serving beam orientation.
Figure 6.3.4.1.3 presents a scheme of HST FR2 in an opposite uni-directional Scenario-A, illustrating the transmission and reception of signals in a high-speed train (HST) environment. The figure showcases the frequency division duplex (FDD) operation, where the uplink and downlink frequencies are separated, allowing for simultaneous transmission and reception. The HST is depicted as a mobile station (MS) connected to a terrestrial network, while the base station (BS) is responsible for signal transmission and reception. The figure highlights the importance of efficient signal management in such scenarios, ensuring seamless communication and minimal interference.
Figure 6.3.4.1.3-1: A scheme of HST FR2 opposite uni-directional Scenario-A.

Figure 6.3.4.1.3 -2 presents a detailed propagation map of a serving Radio Resource Holder (RRH) antenna model without back lobe. The map illustrates the signal strength distribution across various angles and distances, providing valuable insights into the antenna's radiation pattern. The figure showcases how the signal strength varies with the angle of arrival, offering a comprehensive understanding of the antenna's performance in a real-world scenario. The absence of back lobe indicates that the antenna does not radiate energy in the opposite direction, which is crucial for efficient signal transmission and reception.
Figure 6.3.4.1.3-2: Propagation map of the serving RRH, antenna model without back lobe.

The RSRP traces of the serving (RRH1) and target (RRH2) RRHs are shown in Figure 6.3.4.1.3-3 with at different zoom levels. One can observe that the signal level from target RRH get high enough already much earlier than handover happens. However, the source RRH signal drops drastically near the RRH location. In this traced case, the handover happens early enough to transmit control messages even with realistic PDCCH model. It is also obvious that even slight delays in handover initiation will cause source RRH to drop to unreachable levels (e.g., RSRP below -120 dBm).
Figure 6.3.4.1.3 presents RSRP traces of serving and target RRHs at two distinct scales, with vertical lines indicating A3 trigger coordinates, HO completion, and the source RRH location. The figure illustrates the signal strength and handover processes between the serving and target RRHs, providing insights into the network's performance and coverage. Figure 6.3.4.1.3 provides a detailed analysis of RSRP traces from serving and target RRHs across two distinct scales. The figure showcases vertical lines that represent A3 trigger coordinates, HO completion, and the source RRH location, offering insights into the signal strength and handover processes between the serving and target RRHs. This information is crucial for understanding the network's performance and coverage, as well as identifying areas that may require improvement or additional infrastructure.
Figure 6.3.4.1.3-3: RSRP traces of serving and target RRHs at two different scales. Vertical lines show A3 trigger coordinate, HO complete, and source RRH location.

Based on the simulation results and analysis presented above we can conclude that DRX cycle of 80ms shall be used with precautions in uni-directional Scenario-A.
In sections (6.3.4.1.1.3, 6.3.4.1.1.4, 6.3.4.1.1.5, 6.3.4.1.1.6, 6.3.4.1.2.3, 6.3.4.1.2.4, 6.3.4.1.2.5, 6.3.4.1.2.6) it was demonstrated that Scenario-B mobility performance with enhanced RRM requirements in both uni-directional and bi-directional scenarios is sufficient with DRX cycles up to 80 ms. Compared to legacy RRM requirements the mobility robustness measured by mobility failure and time-of-outage rates is significantly improved with enhanced RRM requirements also in Scenario-B.
In sections 6.3.4.1.1.7, 6.3.4.1.1.8, 6.3.4.1.2.7, 6.3.4.1.2.8, it was shown that Scenario-A with bi-directional deployment needs similar precautions for DRX cycle of 80 ms as uni-directional scenario. Also, bi-directional scenario mobility robustness is significantly improved by the enhanced RRM requirements compared to legacy RRM requirements. Multi-panel UE measurement assumption was also shown to have significant impact to mobility robustness particularly in non-DPS scenario. Having UE capability to measure both directions at the same time can benefit mobility robustness.
Mobility performance in tunnel scenarios:
As demonstrated in previous sections (6.3.4.1.2.9, 6.3.4.1.2.10), the train travelling in the direction opposite to serving beam orientation likely experiences mobility challenges. The issue is more more severe than Scenario A as it may occur even when enhanced requirements are used and without DRX enabled. The root cause of such mobility issues is similar to what has been observed in Scenario A, i.e., the sudden drop of the source RSRP level near the source RRH which is due to the close distance between the RRH locations and the track (Dmin). As tunnel deployment has even shorter Dmin and lower DRRH,height, the source signal level drops more extreme causing high probability of mobility failure even when DRX is not enabled.
Figure 6.3.4.1.3-4 presents a detailed scheme illustrating the High Speed Tunnel (HST) Frequency Division Duplex (FR2) system in operation, specifically focusing on the opposite uni-directional Tunnel scenario. The figure showcases the various components involved, including the transmitter (TX), receiver (RX), and the tunnel itself, which facilitates bidirectional communication between the two. The bidirectional nature of the tunnel is highlighted by the presence of two separate paths, one for each direction of data transmission. The figure also emphasizes the role of frequency division duplexing, which allows for efficient use of the available spectrum and improved overall system performance. The layout of the figure provides a clear understanding of how the HST FR2 system operates in the context of the uni-directional Tunnel scenario, offering valuable insights into the design and functionality of such telecommunication systems.
Figure 6.3.4.1.3-4: A scheme of HST FR2 opposite uni-directional Tunnel scenario.
Figure 6.3.4.1.3-5 shows propagation map around the source RRH location (the physical features of the tunnel like reflections are not considered).  Only the source RRH is considered in the pathgain + antenna gain + beam gain of the map. It is observed that there is very strong signal level along the track until the RRH location, and with the backlobe suppressed signal level drops to unusable level right after the RRH if train is moving towards east and RRH antenna is pointed towards west.

Figure 6.3.4.1.3-5 illustrates the propagation map of the serving RRH, focusing on the antenna model without back lobe. The figure showcases the signal's behavior as it travels through the air, reflecting off surrounding objects, and reaching the receiver. The visual representation highlights the importance of antenna design and positioning in enhancing signal reception and reducing interference. The absence of back lobe indicates that the antenna design effectively mitigates signal reflection, resulting in a more focused and efficient transmission path.
Figure 6.3.4.1.3-5: Propagation map of the serving RRH, antenna model without back lobe.
Figure 6.3.4.1.3-6 shows the RSRP traces of the source (RRH1) and target (RRH2) RRHs. It is observed that signal level from the serving beam increases when the train is approaching the source RRH, and suddenly drops drastically when the train is about 5m from the Source RRH location. One can also see that the first A3 event is triggered when the train is right under the source RRH where there is no longer coverage from serving beam. Later, several attempts for triggering A3 events are carried out in order to make HO, but there is no successful HO achieved. This can be understandable as the signal level source RRH has dropped to unreachable level causing the loss of HO command. After staying outage for a significantly long period, the cell selection procedure is initiated to make the UE connecting to the new cell.
Figure 6.3.4.1.3-6 illustrates the RSRP (Received Signal Strength Indicator) traces of a source and target in a telecommunication scenario. The vertical lines represent the A3 trigger coordinate, new cell selection, and the location of the source RRH (Radio Remote Head). The figure provides valuable insights into signal strength and cell selection processes, aiding in the optimization of communication networks.
Figure 6.3.4.1.3-6: RSRP traces of source and target. Vertical lines show A3 trigger coordinate, new cell selection, and source RRH location.
The system simulation results in Sections (6.3.4.1.2.9 and 6.3.4.1.2.10) pointed out the mobility issue for HST FR2 happened inside the tunnel. RAN4 studies concluded that multi-panel reception, in which the UE can receives the DL signals simultaneously from two opposite directions, is a candidate solution for the considered issue, i.e., if one link is failed, the UE still has connections to the network via the other link.
In Section 6.3.4.1.2.11, the mobility robustness was studied for the mobility at the tunnel entrance/exit. In such areas, the coverage of the RRHs outside the tunnel may be limited inside the tunnel due to the blockage of the tunnel outer surfaces. It was demonstrated that time-of-outage and inter-cell mobility failure rate both increase suggesting the potential mobility problem that may occur at the tunnel entrance/exit. Nevertheless, such issue can be resolved by deployment-based solutions, i.e., placing the open-space RRHs which is nearest to the tunnel entrance/exit closer to the railway track, e.g., the RRH2’s location shown in Figure 6.3.4.1.3-7.
Figure 6.3.4.1.3-7 illustrates a special deployment of an open-space Radio Remote Head (RRH) next to the tunnel entrance. This configuration is designed to optimize signal coverage in areas with challenging terrain, such as tunnels or mountainous regions. The figure shows the RRH, which is a type of base station used in wireless communication networks, positioned strategically to ensure seamless connectivity for users in the vicinity. The open-space RRH is particularly useful in scenarios where traditional RRH might not provide adequate signal strength or coverage due to the presence of obstacles or uneven terrain. The deployment also highlights the importance of network planning and optimization in areas with unique geographical features, as it ensures that users can access the network reliably and efficiently, even in remote or difficult-to-reach locations.
Figure 6.3.4.1.3-7: Example of a special deployment for the open-space RRH next to the tunnel entrance.

subsubsections.title: 6.3.7	Maximum supported Speed
subsubsections.text_content:
Companies’ observation on Maximum Speed feasibility:
-	It is feasible to support maximum speed with 350km/h for downlink with TRS (4 symbol interval) for frequency offset tracking under unidirectional RRH deployment with 120KHz SCS.
-	It is feasible to support maximum speed with 350km/h for downlink with TRS (4 symbol interval) +SSB for frequency offset tracking under unidirectional and bi-directional RRH deployment with 120KHz SCS.
-	It is feasible to support maximum speed with 350km/h for downlink with TRS (4 symbol interval) + PTRS (L=1) for frequency offset tracking under bi-directional RRH deployment with 120KHz SCS.
-	It is feasible to support maximum speed with 350km/h for downlink with PTRS or DMRS(1+1+1) + PTRS (L=1,K=2) configuration used for frequency offset tracking under single tap propagation conditions with 120KHz SCS.
Configure PTRS during the PDSCH demodulation test.
RS as baseline for frequency offset tracking to support 350km/h
-	multiple options under discussion.
DMRS configuration for PDSCH demodulation requirement
-	Option 1: 1 DMRS; and
-	Option 2: 1+1+1 DMRS.

subsubsections.title: 6.3.8	Beam dwelling time
subsubsections.text_content:
The system simulation assumptions for beam dwelling time are shown in table 6.3.8.1-1. The simulation results of beam dwelling time are obtained from system-level simulations which were carried out to evaluate legacy RRM requirements under high-speed train scenarios.
Table 6.3.8.1-1: Simulation assumptions for beam dwelling time

The simulation results of beam dwelling time are shown in figures 6.3.8.1-1-3 for unidirectional scenarios with a different number beams transmitted by RRH. The simulation results of beam dwelling time are shown in figures 6.3.8.1-4-6 for bidirectional scenarios with different number of beams transmitted by RRH.
It is worth noting that the simulation results are the average beam dwelling time. In the simulation, beam dwelling time is influenced by beam coverage and beam switching rate (including hysteresis). Beam coverage is discussed in detail in clause 6.3.8.2, where ideal beam dwelling time is investigated.
In the case of multi-beam operation cases shown in figures 6.3.8.1-2, 6.3.8.1-3, 6.3.8.1-5 and 6.3.8.1-6, it can be observed that the dwelling time of Beam 0 is the shortest because the coverage of Beam 0 is the smallest.

Figure 6.3.8.1-1 illustrates the average beam dwelling time with one beam per RRH in unidirectional scenarios. The figure depicts the time duration a user equipment (UE) spends in a single beam before switching to another, represented by the horizontal axis. The vertical axis shows the corresponding average beam dwelling time in milliseconds. The data points are plotted across different signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) levels, ranging from -10 dB to 10 dB, which are crucial for understanding the performance of the radio access network (RAN) in terms of energy efficiency and capacity. The figure highlights the impact of beam management strategies on the overall network performance, particularly in scenarios where there is a single radio access point (RRH) serving multiple UEs.
Figure 6.3.8.1-1: Average beam dwelling time with 1 beam per RRH for unidirectional scenarios

Figure 6.3.8.1-2 illustrates the average beam dwelling time with two beams per Radio Remote Head (RRH) in unidirectional scenarios. The figure depicts the time duration that a specific beam is maintained in a given direction, measured in milliseconds. The x-axis represents the beam dwelling time, while the y-axis represents the frequency in megahertz (MHz). The graph shows two distinct curves, one for the uplink and the other for the downlink, indicating the time spent on each direction. The figure highlights the importance of efficient beam management in enhancing the overall performance of a wireless communication system.
Figure 6.3.8.1-2: Average beam dwelling time with 2 beams per RRH for unidirectional scenarios

Figure 6.3.8.1-3 illustrates the average beam dwelling time with 4 beams per RRH for unidirectional scenarios, showcasing the time a beam focuses on a specific user equipment (UE) in a radio access network (RAN) environment. The figure highlights the importance of efficient beam management in enhancing signal quality and reducing interference. The depicted 4-beam RRH configuration is crucial for optimizing the performance of the network in terms of data transmission and reception.
Figure 6.3.8.1-3: Average beam dwelling time with 4 beams per RRH for unidirectional scenarios

Figure 6.3.8.1-4 illustrates the average beam dwelling time with 1 beam per RRH for bidirectional scenarios, showcasing the time a beam focuses on a user equipment (UE) in a radio access network (RAN) environment. The figure highlights the importance of efficient beam management in enhancing communication quality and reducing interference. Key elements include the base station (gNB), radio access network (RAN), user equipment (UE), and the beam management system. The bidirectional nature of the scenario emphasizes the need for effective coordination between uplink and downlink transmissions.
Figure 6.3.8.1-4: Average beam dwelling time with 1 beam per RRH for bidirectional scenarios

Figure 6.3.8.1-5 illustrates the average beam dwelling time with 2 beams per RRH for bidirectional scenarios, showcasing the time a beam focuses on a specific direction before switching to another. The figure highlights the importance of efficient beam management in enhancing communication quality and reducing interference in multi-antenna systems.
Figure 6.3.8.1-5: Average beam dwelling time with 2 beams per RRH for bidirectional scenarios

Figure 6.3.8.1-6 illustrates the average beam dwelling time with 2 beams per RRH for bidirectional scenarios, showcasing the time a beam remains focused on a user equipment (UE) during uplink and downlink transmissions. The figure highlights the importance of efficient beam management in enhancing network performance and coverage, particularly in scenarios with multiple RRHs (Radio Remote Heads) and UEs. The depicted 2-beam configuration is crucial for reducing interference and improving data rates in both directions.
Figure 6.3.8.1-6: Average beam dwelling time with 2 beams per RRH for bidirectional scenarios

In HST deployment scenarios, the footprint of an RRH beam can be represented by an ellipse as shown in figure 6.3.8.2-1. It is assumed that UE aboard an HST is moving with constant velocity  and its trajectory is a straight line. An RRH is located at the point  in which its antenna array boresight for the th beam is oriented towards a point  which is along the trajectory of UE.
Figure 6.3.8.2-1 illustrates the beam footprint of a Remote Radio Head (RRH), which is a key component in a cellular network. The figure shows the coverage area of the RRH, with the outer circle representing the main beam and the inner circle indicating the partial beam. The beamwidth is a crucial parameter for optimizing the network's capacity and coverage. The figure also highlights the downtilt angle, which affects the signal's strength in the horizontal plane. The visual representation of the beam footprint provides valuable insights for network planning and optimization.
Figure 6.3.8.2-1: RRH beam footprint
